com.statetable.flipflop

Class JKFlipFlop

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.statetable.flipflop.TwoBitFlipFlop
      • com.statetable.flipflop.JKFlipFlop
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    FlipFlop

    public class JKFlipFlop
extends TwoBitFlipFlop
    JK Flip flop augments the behavior of the RS Flip flop (J=SET K=RESET) by interpreting the J=K=1 condition as a flip or toggle command. Specifically, the combination J=1 K=0 is a command to set the flip-flop; the combination J=0 K=1 is a command to reset the flip-flop. Setting J=K=0 does not result in a D Flip flop but rather will hold the current state.

    The JKFlipFlop is an idealization of this definition in code form. It has 4 methods; namely, setCurrentState: which sets the current bit to be stored in the flip-flop, getNextState: which gets the next state according to an implementing flip-flop's "rules" and current state, setFirstBit: which sets the J either 1 or 0, and lastly, setSecondBit: which sets the K either to 0 or 1.

        public void setCurrentState(int currentBit)
        Sets the current state of this flip-flop to some predefined value. It can only have either of 2 values, binary zero and binary one. {0, 1}>
        Specified by:

      • getNextState

        public int getNextState()
        Returns the next state of the bit stored in this flip-flop according to its rules. If J=K=0 then no changes would be made to the current state. If J=0 & K=1, this resets the next state. If J=1 & K=0, this sets the next state. And if J=K=1, the next state toggles or complements the current state.
        Specified by:
        getNextState in interface FlipFlop
        Specified by:
        getNextState in class TwoBitFlipFlop
        Returns:
        the next state of the bit stored in this flip-flop
